item.title: Trump’s Tariff Date Arrives After a 90-Day Rollercoaster
item.description: The world economy, beset with uncertainty for three months over Donald Trump’s on-again-off-again tariffs, is about to get more clarity as the US president’s deadline for trade deals arrives on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Bayport Container Terminal at the port of Houston in Seabrook, Texas, US, on Thursday, May 22, 2025. US businesses are under mounting pressure to import goods while President Donald Trump's higher tariffs are on pause, and they're simultaneously navigating increasingly complex filing rules when their cargo crosses the border.

item.title: ECB’s Makhlouf Says Euro Not Ready to Challenge Dollar’s Role
item.description: The euro cannot quickly supplant the dollar as the anchor of the world’s financial system as countries using it still have far to go in their financial and economic integration, European Central Bank Governing Council member Gabriel Makhlouf said.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: A euro symbol on a sign outside the headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. The European Central Bank is about to lower interest rates for the sixth time since June, though a volatile economic backdrop is sowing divisions over where to take borrowing costs from here. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US Jobs Data Eases Pressure on Fed
item.description: Fresh US jobs figures took pressure off the Federal Reserve to consider an interest-rate cut later this month, likely leaving the central bank on hold at least until the fall.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: Recruiters and job seekers speak during a job fair hosted by the Cook County government to support federal workers in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Thousands of private government consultants laid off during the Trump administration's cost-cutting crusade are increasingly flooding a shrinking labor market.

item.title: Emily Sundberg on How Nobody Is Coming to Save Gen Z
item.description: What today's young people actually think about money.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Emily Sundberg, author of the Feed Me newsletter, speaks on stage at a live taping of the Odd Lots podcast in New York City, on Thursday, June 26, 2025.

item.title: Butter’s Global Price Surge Hits Croissants and Kitchens Alike
item.description: At the Mamiche bakeries in the 9th and 10th arrondissements of Paris, their famous pains au chocolat and croissants depend on an essential but increasingly scarce ingredient — butter.
item.dc:creator: Celia Bergin, Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: A pastry chef prepares croissants for sale at a Bakehouse bakery in the Causeway Bay area of Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, July 25, 2024. Bakery chain Bakehouse opened its account on lifestyle app Xiaohongshu after mainland Chinese users raved about its egg tarts — an iconic Hong Kong dessert — on the social media platform.

item.title: Mozambique Weighs Asking China to Rework Debt, President Says
item.description: Cash-strapped Mozambique is open to asking China to restructure the $1.4 billion it owes its biggest bilateral creditor, President Daniel Chapo said.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Daniel Chapo (center).

item.title: Vietnam’s Growth Surges as Buyers Race to Beat Trump Tariffs
item.description: Vietnam’s growth accelerated in the second quarter as foreign buyers raced to avoid threatened tariffs of as much as 46% on sales to the US.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

media:content.media:description: Motorcyclists and trucks in Binh Duong City, Binh Duong Province, Vietnam, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. With almost half of the $34.5 billion of goods exported out of Binh Duong last year shipped to the US, the region is especially vulnerable to tariff shocks. Photographer: Linh Pham/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Has Nowhere to Go, Stuck Between Rebels and Bond Market
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is caught between a political rebellion and a jittery bond market.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Philip Aldrick, Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, right, and Rachel Reeves in London on July 3. Photographer: Jack Hill/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: South Korea Passes Extra Budget Before Tariff Deadline
item.description: South Korea’s parliament and cabinet approved a 31.8 trillion won ($23.3 billion) extra budget as new President Lee Jae Myung seeks to revive an economy struggling with weak consumption and mounting trade risks from US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: Vietnam Gains Edge With Early Trump Deal, US Group Head Says
item.description: Vietnam’s race to secure a trade deal with the Trump administration, even if the details aren’t clear, gives the Southeast Asian country an advantage over regional rivals, according to Ted Osius, president of the US-Asean Business Council.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

item.title: BOE’s Taylor Warns Neutral Rate Question Can’t Be Avoided
item.description: Bank of England policymaker Alan Taylor said UK officials cannot sidestep the question of where interest rates will settle, in a direct challenge to Governor Andrew Bailey’s approach.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: City workers pass the Bank of England during a heat wave in London, UK, on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. Unusually hot weather is making it almost unbearable to travel on the UK capital’s underground train network.

item.title: India Seeking US Trade Deal Even as it Toughens Stance
item.description: India said it is hoping to secure a trade deal with the US in the coming days amid threats by the South Asian nation to impose retaliatory tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: The Port of Los Angeles. Photographer: Patrick T. Fallon/Getty Images

item.title: BOE Corporate Bond Buying Failed to Aid Firms, Staff Paper Finds
item.description: The Bank of England’s £20 billion ($27.3 billion) of corporate bond purchases failed to lower borrowing costs or boost bond issuance in the primary market, according to the central bank’s own research.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Polish Policymakers See More Cuts Coming as Inflation Eases
item.description: Polish policymakers see room for more interest rate cuts this year, but remain divided over calling them an easing cycle.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: A sign for Narodowy Bank Polski at the central bank's headquarters in Warsaw. Photographer: Damian Lemański/Bloomberg

item.title: US-Swiss Trade Deal Likely to Contain Assurances on Pharma Levy
item.description: The draft of a trade accord between the US and Switzerland contains a provision that the European country will receive preferred treatment in the ongoing national-security investigations to avoid tariffs on pharma exports, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Jenny Leonard

item.title: South Africa Weighs Small Business Registry Amid Jobs Data Furor
item.description: South Africa is considering developing a statistical register for small-scale and informal businesses, amid an ongoing debate about the methodology used to compile the country’s labor statistics.
item.dc:creator: Adelaide Changole

item.title: China Exempts Major EU Brandy Makers From Anti-Dumping Duty
item.description: China imposed anti-dumping duties on European brandy for five years, while exempting major cognac makers that committed to keeping their prices above minimum levels.

item.title: ECB’s Makhlouf Says Inflation Expectations Are Well Anchored
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Gabriel Makhlouf said inflation expectations in the euro area are well anchored and allowed the region to avoid large increases in unemployment during the most recent period of strong consumer-price growth.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Makhlouf Photographer: Sergio Garcia

item.title: Gold-Backed ZiG Climbs Most This Year as Zimbabwe Reserves Surge
item.description: Zimbabwe’s gold-backed ZiG posted its best single-day gain against the dollar this year, boosted by surging bullion output and improved foreign currency reserves.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: A twenty ZiG banknote at a market in Harare, Zimbabwe.

item.title: Thailand to Rework Trade Proposals Before US Tariff Deadline
item.description: Thailand will refine its trade proposal framework as it races to secure a reciprocal tariff deal with the US before the deadline next week, according to Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira, adding that the country’s first ministerial-level talks went well.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

item.title: Trade Deal May Double India Goods Exports to US, Report Says
item.description: A comprehensive trade deal between New Delhi and Washington could significantly boost the South Asian nation’s exports and manufacturing sector, paving the way for sustained growth, according to Bloomberg Economics.
item.dc:creator: Ruchi Bhatia

item.title: Faster Inflation Dims Prospect for Further Czech Rate Cuts
item.description: Czech inflation accelerated in June to the fastest pace this year, boosting the odds that policymakers will refrain from further interest-rate cuts at least in the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Krystof Chamonikolas

item.title: French Minister Says 10% Tariffs Is Not a Good Deal for EU
item.description: French Industry Minister Marc Ferracci said agreeing to 10% tariffs on European exports to the US would be a bad deal, signaling disapproval of a potential compromise with Washington.

item.title: ECB Risks 2% Undershoot If Euro Strength Persists, Villeroy Says
item.description: The European Central Bank is at greater risk of undershooting its inflation target following a sharp appreciation of the exchange rate, Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.

item.description: UK commercial building activity dropped at the sharpest rate in over five years amid a challenging economic backdrop and lower investment spending, according to a closely watched survey.

item.description: Japan’s inflation is surprisingly strong, increasing the possibility that the Bank of Japan will raise its interest rate by the end of the year, according to one of the country’s leading inflation experts.
